metadata.sermon_title: Silver and Gold on the Last Day
metadata.sermon_start_end: Every year, as the last leaves drop from the trees and we start hunkering down for winter, the church’s theological clock starts to tick faster. Beginning after All Saints’ Day, the Scripture readings build to a tremendous crescendo. There is nothing else like it in the church calendar. [...] Well done, thou good and faithful servants; you have been faithful in a little; I will set you over much. Enter into the joy of your Master. Amen.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails to focus on one specific Bible passage. It treats Zephaniah, Revelation, and Matthew as a thematic cluster about judgment and money. According to Dekker, this is a speech about a 'biblical idea' rather than a sermon on a pericope. It misses the specific 'NOWHERE else' quality of Zephaniah by blending it into a general apocalyptic mood.
quotes: In the oracles of the Hebrew prophets, in the letters of Saint Paul, in the parables told by Jesus... the message is the same.
The message of the coming season of Advent is: oh, yes, he will.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select either the Zephaniah text or the Parable of the Talents as the primary object. Do not use other texts to harmonize the message, but let the specific text dictate the unique angle on God and the world.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is a basic awareness of the historical weight of the texts (e.g., the 'talent' as a coin), but it lacks deep linguistic or historical-critical exposition. The use of the 'Dies Irae' is a liturgical/cultural history reference rather than biblical exegesis of Zephaniah's specific Judean context.
quotes: It’s unfortunate that the English word 'talent' is also the name of a coin in Roman times.
There is a stunning thirteenth-century Latin poem based on this text from Zephaniah.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the specific historical situation of Zephaniah's Jerusalem or the specific economic reality of the first-century audience to ground the exposition in its original 'meaning for the first readers'.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete regarding the 'Pledge Sunday' context and the use of money. It avoids vague 'be kind' moralisms by addressing the specific act of giving. However, it leans toward a general 'zeitgeist' of consumerism rather than a sharp, specific application of the text's unique demands.
quotes: We bear witness to our allegiance to the kingdom of God by giving away a lot of our money.
As you sign your pledge card today, the overarching vision is to signify that great day to come.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Connect the application more directly to the 'misery' of our specific economic attachments rather than just the act of pledging to the church.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is structured in blocks. The preacher explicitly signals transitions ('So this is the first part... Now for a change of pace'), which Dekker warns makes the sermon 'boring' and the 'present of revelation' less likely to occur. The hearer is not drawn into the text but observes it from a distance.
quotes: So this is the first part of the sermon this morning. Where do we go from here?
Now for a change of pace—sort of.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Avoid explicit structural markers. Weave the contemporary financial reality directly into the reading of the Zephaniah or Matthew text so that the text 'expounds' the hearer.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon strongly addresses 'misery' (the sickness unto death, the judgment on greed) and 'redemption' (liberation from acquisitiveness). It avoids being overly objective by making the judgment personal. The 'gratitude' is present in the call to stewardship as a response to grace.
quotes: Clearly we are all implicated in a sickness unto death that afflicts the entire human race.
He was offering the young man his freedom... a life in which we are able to stand back from our small preoccupations.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Ensure the 'misery' is not just a general human condition but the specific misery of the 'traders' mentioned in Zephaniah.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: This is a strong point. The sermon takes the 'dreadful day of judgment' seriously and rejects the 'liberal' tendency to expunge it. It presents the ultimate possibilities of life design (being lost in time/eternity vs. the joy of the Master).
quotes: The joke is that while the Prayer Book revisers were busy pushing the dreadful day of judgment out of camera range, the lectionary committees were bringing it back in.
Whoever you are, whoever I am, we are going to be caught up in the judgment of God.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Maintain this sharpness but ground it more in the specific 'lostness' described in the chosen pericope.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is the telos, but the sermon occasionally slips into a moralistic call to action (giving money) as the primary focus. While Christ is mentioned as the judge and the one who liberates, the 'doctrine of the two natures' and the 'salvation outside himself' could be more central to the resolution.
quotes: The One who does the reckoning is Jesus Christ.
Jesus knows we have trouble with money; that’s why he brings us a new life.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Focus more on Christ as the 'One Lord' who has already fulfilled the investment God requires, rather than just the one who 'invites' us to be free.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 2100 words, the sermon meets the 20-minute threshold. It allows for the 'breadth' that Miskotte and Dekker require for theological depth.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Use the available time to go deeper into the specific text rather than covering multiple biblical books.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's ideal primarily by failing the 'one specific passage' rule; it is a thematic synthesis of several texts rather than an exposition of one. It also suffers from a segmented structure where exposition and application are separated by explicit transitions. However, it is strong in its refusal to shy away from the 'two ways' and the reality of judgment, and it successfully addresses the human subject through the lens of misery and redemption.
strengths: Theological courage in maintaining the 'dreadful day of judgment' against modern sensibilities.
Adequate length allowing for the development of a complex theme (money and eternity).
Concrete application that avoids vague spiritualization of the 'talents'.
weaknesses: Lack of focus on a single pericope, leading to a 'general biblical truth' rather than a specific word.
Mechanical separation of exposition and application ('change of pace').
Insufficient use of original languages or historical-critical depth in the exposition.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a substantial religious speech that takes God and man seriously, but it is not yet a 'sermon' in the strict Dekkerian sense because it lacks the concentration on a specific, unique Bible passage and the seamless interweaving of text and hearer.
